title: 1334-F
statement: F. Strange Functiontime limit per test3 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputLet's denote the following function $$$f$$$. This function takes an array $$$a$$$ of length $$$n$$$ and returns an array. Initially the result is an empty array. For each integer $$$i$$$ from $$$1$$$ to $$$n$$$ we add element $$$a_i$$$ to the end of the resulting array if it is greater than all previous elements (more formally, if $$$a_i > \\max\\limits_{1 \\le j < i}a_j$$$). Some examples of the function $$$f$$$:if $$$a = [3, 1, 2, 7, 7, 3, 6, 7, 8]$$$ then $$$f(a) = [3, 7, 8]$$$;if $$$a = [1]$$$ then $$$f(a) = [1]$$$;if $$$a = [4, 1, 1, 2, 3]$$$ then $$$f(a) = [4]$$$;if $$$a = [1, 3, 1, 2, 6, 8, 7, 7, 4, 11, 10]$$$ then $$$f(a) = [1, 3, 6, 8, 11]$$$.You are given two arrays: array $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots , a_n$$$ and array $$$b_1, b_2, \\dots , b_m$$$. You can delete some elements of array $$$a$$$ (possibly zero). To delete the element $$$a_i$$$, you have to pay $$$p_i$$$ coins (the value of $$$p_i$$$ can be negative, then you get $$$|p_i|$$$ coins, if you delete this element). Calculate the minimum number of coins (possibly negative) you have to spend for fulfilling equality $$$f(a) = b$$$.InputThe first line contains one integer $$$n$$$ $$$(1 \\le n \\le 5 \\cdot 10^5)$$$ — the length of array $$$a$$$.The second line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ $$$(1 \\le a_i \\le n)$$$ — the array $$$a$$$.The third line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$p_1, p_2, \\dots, p_n$$$ $$$(|p_i| \\le 10^9)$$$ — the array $$$p$$$.The fourth line contains one integer $$$m$$$ $$$(1 \\le m \\le n)$$$ — the length of array $$$b$$$.The fifth line contains $$$m$$$ integers $$$b_1, b_2, \\dots, b_m$$$ $$$(1 \\le b_i \\le n, b_{i-1} < b_i)$$$ — the array $$$b$$$.OutputIf the answer exists, in the first line printYES. In the second line, print the minimum number of coins you have to spend for fulfilling equality $$$f(a) = b$$$.Otherwise in only line printNO.ExamplesInput11 4 1 3 3 7 8 7 9 10 7 11 3 5 0 -2 5 3 6 7 8 2 4 3 3 7 10OutputYES 20Input6 2 1 5 3 6 5 3 -9 0 16 22 -14 4 2 3 5 6OutputNO

processed.result:
You are given two arrays,  $a$ of length $n$ and $b$ of length $m$.  

Array $a$ contains integers from 1 to $n$.  You can delete elements from array $a$. Deleting the $i$-th element costs $p_i$ coins.  

The function $f(a)$ works as follows:

1. Start with an empty array.
2. For each integer $i$ from 1 to $n$, if $a_i$ is greater than all previous elements in $a$, add $a_i$ to the end of the array.

The goal is to find the minimum number of coins you need to spend deleting elements from $a$ so that $f(a) = b$.

If it's impossible to make $f(a) = b$, output "NO". Otherwise, output "YES" followed by the minimum number of coins.

You are given two arrays, `a` and `b`.  You can remove elements from array `a` and receive coins based on the value of `p` associated with each element. The goal is to remove elements from `a` so that the remaining elements, in order, are the same as array `b`.  

Find the minimum total coins you need to spend to achieve this. If it's impossible, say "no".
